candidates.title: feat(swc/plugin): support `context` for the plugin transform
candidates.body:
<!-- Thanks for submitting a pull request! Please provide enough information so that others can review your pull request. -->

**Description:**

From discussion https://github.com/swc-project/swc/discussions/3540#discussioncomment-2163757. 

Plugin may need additional data other than config to plugin itself, mostly state around swc/core. Some examples like

- specific file name for current transform
- maybe whole swcrc config, not only for the plugin itself

or possibly more. This PR attempts to resolve those by forwarding new param named `context`.

There are few possible approaches to enable this.

1. expand plugin interface param signature
```
#[plugin_transform]
fn process(program: Program, plugin_config: String, filename: String, swcrc: String...);
```

Obviously, this is not preferrable as we'll continously expand signatures and each time we add new param it'll cause breaking changes.

2. Typed struct param
```
struct PluginContext {
 filename: String,
 other: ...
}

#[plugin_transform]
fn process(program: Program, plugin_config: String, context: PluginContext);
```

This is most clear interface signature. However, have same pitfall as first. Each time we add new properties into struct, it'll be a breaking change since our serialization does not support add-only / versioned

3. Context as JSON-string

Current approach. Safe to add new properties since it's string, plugin can try to pick up necessary properties for their use.


Though I picked 3rd, I'm currently bit debating 2 also - if we can add enough context properties in experimental phase, we can stabilize those to avoid frequent breaking changes. The part I'm not sure is how frequent we'll need to change this context information. Would like to hear thoughts, and update PR into second if needed.

**BREAKING CHANGE:**
Plugin will need to accept 3rd param in any case, it could be a string or a typed struct.

**Related issue (if exists):**

https://github.com/swc-project/swc/discussions/3540#discussioncomment-2163757.

candidates.title: feat(swc/plugin_runner): improve resolver support for npm
candidates.body:
<!-- Thanks for submitting a pull request! Please provide enough information so that others can review your pull request. -->

**Description:**

PR attempts to close #3548 to generate simple package.json.

Also change includes resolver changes for the plugin. Now plugin is a single packge to .wasm instead of having per-platform optionaldeps, instead of using custom resolver tries to reuse existing node_resolver. It seems to work reasonably, however might need second eye if it's right location to create resolver.

**Related issue (if exists):**

- closes https://github.com/swc-project/swc/issues/3548

candidates.title: feat(swc/cli): plugin scaffolding command
candidates.body:
<!-- Thanks for submitting a pull request! Please provide enough information so that others can review your pull request. -->

**Description:**

PR introduces initial cli features from native swc cli to create plugin project as well as few bikesheddings.

1. swc cli

Introducing a subcommand named `plugin`, provides utilities for the plugin. For now there is only one subcommand.

```
swc plugin new {name} --target-type=wasm32-wasi
```

One of debate was what should be main subcommand for the plugin creation. I considered below two, and choose path to use `plugin` as main subcommand.

```
swc new --type=plugin ...
swc plugin new ...
```

This is slighlty different to future subcommand swc will support, like `compile`, `bundle`, `minify` which is a verb to the action. However, if we choose `new` as main subcommand further plugin-scoped feature will be scattered around each verb-command. Choosing `plugin` as subcommand allows consolidating any other features.

Implementation of scaffolding is very thin and naive. Mostly, it mimics behavior of what `cargo new` does.

- have embedded string based template for the files we'll generate
- directly write files, do not rely on packages like `cargo-generate` or similar template scaffolding
- rely on system's `git` binary instead of trying to embed git / libgit.

This is mostly due to we only need to write 4-5 files at maximum which doesn't require any heavy templating. Decisions to not embed libgit is to avoid heavy dependencies as well as build time. This is not a firm decision, if we're going to expand usage of git / other vcs other than one invocation (`git init`) we may revisit this. 

Lastly, PR includes change to rename `[plugin_module]` macro to `[plguin_transform]`. This'll indicate macro will be used for the transform plugin more clearly.


**BREAKING CHANGE:**
- `plugin_module` is renamed to `plugin_transform`.

**Related issue (if exists):**

https://github.com/swc-project/swc/issues/3311

candidates.title: chore(build): Disable LTO for local builds
candidates.body:
**Description:**


LTO makes local builds too slow, so we disable it from local builds and enable it only for production builds by using `CARGO_PROFILE_RELEASE_LTO: "fat"`

candidates.title: feat(swc/plugin): implement proxy for Mark::fresh
candidates.body:
<!-- Thanks for submitting a pull request! Please provide enough information so that others can review your pull request. -->

**Description:**

Partial implementation for https://github.com/swc-project/swc/issues/3309, before applying same practices, would like to confirm this would bea feasiblee approach.

As similar to previous implementation with plugin_runtime, this PR implements proxy fn for the globals (Mark::fresh in here) which calls host fn when it's being called in plugin's context. Unlike other imported fn signature this doesn't do serialization or copy bytes across memories as Mark is wrapper to u32 value. Fn passes over values directly then each context construct Mark as needed.

**BREAKING CHANGE:**

- DUMMY_SP moved into swc_plugin::syntax_pos namespace.

**Related issue (if exists):**

- #3309

candidates.title: feat(swc/plugin): support global HANDLER in plugin context
candidates.body:
<!-- Thanks for submitting a pull request! Please provide enough information so that others can review your pull request. -->

**Description:**

Followup changes to https://github.com/swc-project/swc/issues/3308 to support better ergonomics around sharing host context.

This PR follows suggested discussion from https://github.com/swc-project/swc/issues/3309#issuecomment-1020968828. PR creates / exports global `HANDLER` to the plugin side by resembling existing scoped_thread_local's interface (specifically, `HANDLER.with`) with existing emitter in the plugin's side. Primary goal for this change is preserving user ergonomics around `HANDLER`: as test case updated, now either plugin or host would use `HANDLER.with` with provided `swc_common::Handler` for same interfaces. 

One of change to support those was lazy initialization of HANDLER in plugin's context via oncecell. This allows us to create a proper handler per each plugin's context. It requires having stub sync impl, however we know plugin will not require thread safety at all.

**BREAKING CHANGE:**
Pretty much unused, but `HostContext` is removed again.

**Related issue (if exists):**
- https://github.com/swc-project/swc/issues/3308
